awd_titl_txt: Continuous Atmospheric Pressure Atomic Layer Deposition Process for Controlled Nanoscale Thin Film Coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research project is to expand the understanding of Atomic layer deposition (ALD) operation at atmospheric pressure and open new opportunities for low cost high speed coating.New methods to produce thin film coatings for electronic devices and improved textile materials are important for passivation and protection, and can provide new function. Most common methods are not compatible with temperature and throughput needed for coating high surface area polymer fibers.  ALD is a relatively new coating process that can produce extremely well controlled coatings at low temperatures compatible with plastics.  One downside to ALD is that it generally requires samples to be placed in a vacuum chamber, which can be costly and slow.
  
The work has the potential for broad impact because it will define a new methodology for nanomanufacturing of organic electronics and nonwoven fiber surface stabilization.  The work will advance discovery through the work of two PhD graduate students.  Students from underrepresented groups will be recruited to participate. Research infrastructure will be enhanced by supporting existing shared user facilities, and by expanding the availability of ALD reactors at NC State.  The PIs will also introduce these Nanotechnology concepts to middle and high school students through their participation in annual NC State University sponsored events.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this project is that it created new fundamental understanding of chemical reactions in nanoscale thin film deposition and coating, important in advanced solar energy conversion, electronic device fabrication, and for protective and encapsulation layers for polymers and textiles. Specifically, two PhD students at North Carolina State University worked with two faculty members to explore thin film coating reactions that occur during chemically self-limiting atomic layer deposition.  Atomic layer deposition is chemical process widely used in advanced semiconductor manufacturing, but it is typically performed in expensive vacuum-based equipment, where only one piece is coated at a time.  We worked to understand if this chemical process could be performed at atmospheric pressure, allowing the coating to proceed in a continuous process, so that future manufacturing could be done with lower cost and higher coating rates.  We discovered and showed that the atomic layer deposition method was readily scalable to atmospheric pressure, with some differences that we understood in terms of gas flow dynamics at atmospheric pressure.  

This project also had broader impact, because it helped support the PhD education of two graduate researchers, one in Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, and one in Textile Engineering, enabling them to build skills that they can use in future jobs to create new high-technology products. Moreover, this project impacts directly the area of low-cost nanoscale thin film coating technology, contributing to the growing need for nanoscale-controlled chemical manufacturing processes.


Last Modified: 07/01/2014
Modified by: Gregory N. Parsons
